Follow a professor of drama as he takes a sabbatical leave and tours around the
world, recording his impressions of people and places in such places as Taipai,
Delhi, Singapore, Cairo and Rome.
After eighteen years of active work in dramatics, Don Buell, Professor of
Speech, Michigan State University, was granted a six month sabbatical leave to
nake a theatre junket around the wor3.d, He found little theatre outside New
ifork, Japan and Italy, but with the dramatist*s eye, and the reporter*s.curi¬
osity he records those vivid first impressions of a not-so-average tourist as
he makes his first trip around the world. Not posing as an expert in political
science or history, Mr, Buell tried to catch the man-on-the-street feeling of
Japan, Formosa, Manila, Hong Kong, Malaya, Thailand, Geylon, India, Egypt, and
Italy as the Cargo-Liner on which he and his party were passengers stopped over
in the major and not-so-major ports of the world.
With the interest in travel, and the great number of tourists who are en route
these days, this series promises to be of interest to all listeners: those who
have been, those who are planning to go, and those who are longing to go. After
broadcasting weekly for 17 years over WKAR in a report of theatre news and re¬
views, Mr. Buell is thoroughly at home before the microphone, and these years
of ad libbing about the theatre have stood him in good stead on this present
series. The programs are entertaining, yet educational, and catch the human
side of those countries that are making tomorrow*s headlines.
